title: Right Ear Fullness and Mixed Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I feel congested with a sense of fullness in my right ear. My hearing in that ear has decreased recently, though it has always been worse than my left.

problem_summary.onset: Recent decrease in the past few weeks.
problem_summary.course: Acute worsening of hearing and fullness coinciding with seasonal allergies; background of chronic poorer hearing in the right ear.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral tinnitus; Right ear hearing loss and fullness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Decreased hearing ability, particularly in the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Resolution of congestion and hearing improvement.

history.present_illness: Patient reports recent hearing decrease and fullness in the right ear coinciding with worsening seasonal allergies.
history.otologic_history: Right ear has historically been poorer than the left. Bilateral tinnitus.
history.noise_exposure_history: History of noise exposure from racing cars throughout his life.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows slight to mild mixed hearing loss (250-2000 Hz) sloping to severe sensorineural loss in high frequencies. Left ear shows normal hearing sloping to a mild sensorineural notch at 4000 Hz.

numeric_results.Right_AC: 25-50 dB HL (250-2kHz), sloping to 80-90 dB HL (4-8kHz)
numeric_results.Right_BC: Better than AC in lows (Air-Bone Gap present)
numeric_results.Left_AC: 10-20 dB HL (250-3kHz), 45 dB HL notch at 4kHz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores agree with PTA. Word recognition is excellent in the left ear and good but slightly reduced in the right ear.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows excessive negative pressure and hypocompliance (Type C/As). Left ear is normal (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes absent (consistent with conductive pathology). Left ipsilateral present 500-2k Hz. Left contralateral (probe right) absent.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with an asymmetric hearing configuration. The left ear exhibits normal hearing with a noise-notch pattern at 4000 Hz, consistent with noise exposure history. The right ear demonstrates a mixed hearing loss: a conductive component in the low-to-mid frequencies (supported by negative middle ear pressure and absent reflexes) overlaid on a sloping sensorineural loss. The conductive component correlates with the reported congestion and allergies.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a 'mixed' loss in the right ear. This means there is likely some permanent hearing loss (nerve-related) combined with a temporary issue related to your middle ear.
The pressure test confirms your right eardrum is stiff and retracted, likely due to Eustachian tube dysfunction caused by your allergies.
The 'notch' in your hearing at 4000 Hz in the left ear is consistent with your history of racing cars and noise exposure.

We are referring you to an ENT specialist to manage the allergy/sinus issues and the asymmetry in your hearing. Treating the allergies may improve the 'fullness' and recover some hearing in the right ear.
It is important to continue protecting your hearing around loud noises to prevent further permanent damage.
notes_for_actor: Portray the patient as bothered by the sensation of fullness/plugging in the right ear more than the hearing loss itself.
Mention the racing car history casually as a fact of life.
Emphasize the connection between the recent seasonal allergy flare-up and the ear symptoms.
